description:
The Torque teno midi virus 1 (TTMDV-1) is a small, non-enveloped DNA virus that belongs to the Anelloviridae family. It is a member of the genus Betatorquevirus, which is one of the four genera within the Anelloviridae family.

TTMDV-1 is a circular, single-stranded DNA virus with a genome size of approximately 3.2 to 3.3 kilobases. The viral genome encodes several open reading frames (ORFs) that are responsible for the production of various viral proteins, including the viral capsid protein and non-structural proteins involved in viral replication and assembly.

The Torque teno midi viruses, including TTMDV-1, are known to be widely distributed in the human population and are commonly found in the blood and other body fluids of healthy individuals. However, the exact role and clinical significance of these viruses in human health and disease are still under investigation.

Ongoing research aims to better understand the epidemiology, prevalence, and potential associations between TTMDV-1 and various human health conditions. The study of these viruses may provide insights into the complex interactions between the human host and the diverse viral communities that reside within the human body.
